15.heading: Chinese Americans.
15.title: "The Yellow Deserter"
15.author: Anthony Tallarico
15.appears_in: 6 p. in Fighting War Stories, no. 2 (Oct. 1952).
notes: Begins: "When Joe Riley, the B.A.R. man in Sergeant Mallard's squad, was killed in action in Korea, he was replaced by Tommy Lee, a young Chinese-American. Tommy soon found that the battle with the Chinese communists was not the only one he had to fight, and that he'd have to go further than most men to prove that he was an American soldier."

38.heading: Chinese Clothing.
38.title: "Flight to Alaska"
38.author: by Capt
38.appears_in: A.E. Carruthers ; art: Joe Doolin. 8 p. in Wings Comics, no. 30 (Feb. 1943).
notes: Summary: Hinda has Suicide meet her in Chinatown in San Francisco, and they are attacked by Japanese men in Chinese clothing. Suicide kills three, but a fourth escapes to Elkhorn, Alaska, where a combined Japanese and German operation is leaving for Tokyo.
Data from Lou Mougin via The Grand Comics Database Project.

198.heading: Chinese Communists.
198.title: "Commando Strike"
198.author: by Rollin W
198.appears_in: Bell ; art: Robert Webb. 5 p. in Fight Comics, no. 82 (Sept. 1952).
notes: Introduction of Major Crawford, and the "guerilla girl"; villains are Chinese communists.
Includes diagram of a top secret "television torpedo."
Data from Gene Reed via Grand Comic Book Database.

199.heading: Chinese Communists.
199.title: "The Human Bombs"
199.author: art: Robert Webb
notes: Begins: "Explosions of mysterious origin harassing Allied troops!"
Shown is the "trans-cranial-electra process" used by the communists for brainwashing.
Villains are Ho-Tong (introduced and dies here) and Chinese Communists; also introduced is Madame Chi-Ling.
Data from Gene Reed via Grand Comic Book Database.

200.heading: Chinese Communists.
200.title: "The Yellow Deserter"
200.author: Anthony Tallarico
200.appears_in: 6 p. in Fighting War Stories, no. 2 (Oct. 1952).
notes: Begins: "When Joe Riley, the B.A.R. man in Sergeant Mallard's squad, was killed in action in Korea, he was replaced by Tommy Lee, a young Chinese-American. Tommy soon found that the battle with the Chinese communists was not the only one he had to fight, and that he'd have to go further than most men to prove that he was an American soldier."

205.appears_in: R. Williams. p. 74 in Cowboys Out Our Way (New York : Scribner, 1951).
notes: Summary: The Chinese cook is practicing horsemanship before a forty-mile ride.

206.heading: Chinese Cooks.
206.title: "The Phosofish and the Serum"
206.author: [No author]
206.series: Captain Gallant and His Mini-Sub) 7 p. in Super-Mystery Comics, v. 1, no. 4
notes: Begins: "Captain Gallant, young scientist-adventurer, sails the seas in his mini-sub with Peg-Leg Parsons, his assistant, and Chop Ching, Oriental chief cook and bottlewasher."

207.heading: Chinese Cooks.
207.title: "A Slick Scheme to Duck That Chinese Cooking"
207.author: by Harry O'Neill.
notes: Summary: The Boy Rangers are determined not to eat Ming Ling's cooking, and visit the Girl Rangers for handouts.

208.heading: Chinese Cooks.
208.title: "The Survivor"
208.author: J
notes: Summary: The Chinese cook says he enjoyed the trip, and the cowboys wonder what kind of nut philosophy he has since the trip nearly killed him.

209.heading: Chinese Cooks.
209.title: "The Whipping Post"
209.author: J
209.appears_in: R. Williams. p. 75 in Cowboys Out Our Way (New York : Scribner, 1951).
notes: Summary: The Chinese cook is in pain from his ride, and the cowboys have him tied across the saddle.

210.heading: Chinese Culture Series.
210.title: Three Character Classic in Comics
210.author: translated by Xu Chuiyang ; illustrated by Mai Rongbang.
notes: Used as a children's primer for hundreds of years. Compiled by Southern Song scholar Wang Yinglin (Baihou) and amended from dynasty to dynasty.

Chinese and English text. 1. Chinese comics. 2. Educational comic books, strips, etc. I. Chuiyang, Xu. II. Rongbang, Mai. III. Wang, Ying-lin, 1223-1296. IV. Series. V. EPB Publishers. Call no.: PL1115.T47 1993
